Islands Architecture

Islands Architecture enables partial hydration, shipping only the JavaScript needed for interactive components while keeping the rest as static HTML.

What are Islands?

Islands Architecture is a rendering pattern where most of your page is static HTML, with isolated "islands" of interactivity that get hydrated independently. This approach dramatically reduces JavaScript bundle size and improves Time to Interactive (TTI).

page.tsxtypescript
1// Static content - no JavaScript shipped
2function Header() {
3  return (
4    <header>
5      <h1>Welcome to our site</h1>
6      <nav>{/* Static navigation */}</nav>
7    </header>
8  );
9}
10 
11// Interactive island - only this ships JavaScript
12import { island } from 'philjs-core';
13 
14const CounterIsland = island(() => import('./Counter'));
15 
16function Page() {
17  return (
18    <>
19      <Header />
20      <main>
21        <p>This is static content.</p>
22        <CounterIsland client:visible />
23      </main>
24    </>
25  );
26}

Creating Islands

Basic Island

1import { island } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Create an island from a component
4const MyIsland = island(() => import('./MyComponent'));
5 
6// Use in your page
7function Page() {
8  return (
9    <div>
10      <MyIsland
11        client:load      // Hydrate immediately on load
12        fallback={<Spinner />}
13        someProp="value"
14      />
15    </div>
16  );
17}

Hydration Strategies

PhilJS supports multiple hydration strategies to control when islands become interactive:

1// Hydrate immediately when the page loads
2<Island client:load />
3 
4// Hydrate when the island becomes visible in viewport
5<Island client:visible />
6 
7// Hydrate when the browser is idle
8<Island client:idle />
9 
10// Hydrate on user interaction (hover, focus, or click)
11<Island client:hover />
12<Island client:focus />
13<Island client:click />
14 
15// Hydrate when a media query matches
16<Island client:media="(min-width: 768px)" />
17 
18// Never hydrate (useful for static content that uses islands infra)
19<Island client:only />
i

Default Strategy

If no hydration directive is specified, islands use client:visible by default for optimal performance.

Passing Props to Islands

Props are serialized and passed to islands during hydration. Only serializable data types are supported:

1const ProductIsland = island(() => import('./ProductCard'));
2 
3function ProductPage({ product }) {
4  return (
5    <ProductIsland
6      client:visible
7      // Serializable props
8      id={product.id}
9      name={product.name}
10      price={product.price}
11      imageUrl={product.imageUrl}
12      // Objects and arrays work too
13      variants={product.variants}
14      metadata={{ featured: true }}
15    />
16  );
17}
18 
19// Functions and class instances cannot be serialized
20// This would cause an error:
21// <Island onClick={handleClick} />  // Error!

Nested Islands

Islands can contain other islands for complex interactive sections:

1const DashboardIsland = island(() => import('./Dashboard'));
2const ChartIsland = island(() => import('./Chart'));
3const FiltersIsland = island(() => import('./Filters'));
4 
5function DashboardPage() {
6  return (
7    <DashboardIsland client:load>
8      {/* These islands hydrate independently */}
9      <FiltersIsland client:idle />
10      <ChartIsland client:visible />
11    </DashboardIsland>
12  );
13}

Islands in Rust

page.rsrust
1use philjs::prelude::*;
2 
3// Define an island component
4#[island]
5fn Counter(initial: i32) -> Element {
6    let count = use_signal(|| initial);
7 
8    view! {
9        <button on:click=move |_| count.set(|c| c + 1)>
10            "Count: " {count}
11        </button>
12    }
13}
14 
15// Use in a page
16#[component]
17fn Page() -> Element {
18    view! {
19        <div>
20            <h1>"Static Content"</h1>
21            // Hydrate when visible
22            <Counter initial=0 client:visible />
23        </div>
24    }
25}

Shared State Between Islands

Islands can share state using PhilJS stores or context that's initialized on the server:

1// store.ts - Shared store
2import { createStore } from 'philjs-core';
3 
4export const [cartStore, setCart] = createStore({
5  items: [],
6  total: 0,
7});
8 
9// CartButton island
10export function CartButton() {
11  return (
12    <button>
13      Cart ({cartStore.items.length})
14    </button>
15  );
16}
17 
18// CartDropdown island
19export function CartDropdown() {
20  return (
21    <div>
22      {cartStore.items.map(item => (
23        <CartItem key={item.id} item={item} />
24      ))}
25      <p>Total: ${cartStore.total}</p>
26    </div>
27  );
28}
29 
30// Both islands share the same store state

Configuration

vite.config.tstypescript
1// vite.config.ts
2import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
3import philjs from 'philjs-compiler/vite';
4 
5export default defineConfig({
6  plugins: [
7    philjs({
8      islands: {
9        // Enable islands mode
10        enabled: true,
11        // Directory containing island components
12        islandsDir: 'src/islands',
13        // Default hydration strategy
14        defaultStrategy: 'visible',
15        // Preload islands for faster hydration
16        preload: true,
17      },
18    }),
19  ],
20});

Performance Tips

  • Use client:visible for below-the-fold content: Only hydrate components when users scroll to them
  • Prefer client:idle for non-critical UI: Let the browser prioritize critical rendering
  • Keep islands small: Break large interactive sections into smaller islands
  • Share code between islands: Common utilities are deduplicated automatically
  • Use static content where possible: Not everything needs to be an island

Debugging Islands

1// Enable island debugging in development
2import { configureIslands } from 'philjs-core';
3 
4configureIslands({
5  debug: true,           // Log hydration events
6  showBoundaries: true,  // Highlight island boundaries
7  timing: true,          // Log hydration timing
8});
